Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs on this group proposal intend to work on the following projects. Grossman plans to study different aspects of flavor physics. This includes traditional probes like B meson, D meson and K-meson physics, but also new ones, like top production and decays, and flavor aspects of physics beyond the standard model. Csaki and Perelstein plan to focus their attention on understanding the structure and signatures of models of electroweak symmetry breaking and of hierarchy stabilization, including supersymmetric, extra-dimensional and little Higgs models. Once the LHC experiments start, they expect to focus on theoretical interpretation of the data, with the ultimate goal of determining the mechanism of electroweak symmetry breaking. They will also work on issues at the interface of particle physics and cosmology, aiming to understand the implications of the LHC data for cosmological questions such as the nature of dark matter and the dynamics of the electroweak phase transition. In string theory, McAllister and Tye propose to study certifications that result in stabilized moduli, and to use
these setups to find realistic implementations of inflation in string theory. This provides a rigorous framework for resolving theoretical issues in inflation, and also provides the best prospect for experimental constraints on string theory. McAllister and Tye will pursue both aspects of this connection. Lepage proposes to use lattice simulations to finnd theoretical predictions for B and D meson physics observables at the few percent level, some of which will be compared to forthcoming results from CLEO-c. Kinoshita is proposing to calculate the eighth and tenth order QED contributions to the lepton g - 2,
which will enable the most precise determination of the fine structure constant and also give the most stringent tests of QED. On the more formal side, LeClair is proposing to study quantum field theories in lower dimensions, with potential applications to condensed matter systems and string theory. The group is committed to training the next generation of theoretical physicists especially in the areas of LHC Physics and Cosmology. The Cornell particle theory group regularly lecture at the local high school and at the local chapter of SPS, and participate in a wide range of outreach activities
both locally and abroad. Being part of the Laboratory for Elementary Particle Physics (LEPP) at Cornell provides unique opportunities for interactions with experimental colleagues working on CLEO-c and the CMS experiment at the LHC and the group provides theoretical support for the experimental program.

This grant supported research conducted by the Particle Theory Group at Cornell University between 2009 and 2013, led by seven faculty members (Csaki, Grossman, Kinoshita, LeClair, Lepage, McAllister and Perelstein). In this funding period 203 papers were published in peer-reviewed journals, and 16 graduate students obtained PhD's as a result of partial support from this grant. In addition, 7 postdocs were partly or fully funded by this grant.


Csaki's research has been focusing on physics beyond the Standard Model and the physics of the TeV scale, and in particular on electroweak symmetry breaking and flavor models. He has examined various types of supersymmetric extensions of the Standard Model, including one where light third generation superpartners naturally arise from strong dynamics. He has also produced a series of papers on novel implementations of R-parity violation.  Another line of Csaki's research has been the investigation of dilaton-like particles, which he applied as a field that can play the role of the recently discovered Higgs boson, or that of the inflaton.

 

Perelstein’s work focused on theoretical interpretation of the data from the Large Hadron Collider, and on exploration of the physics case for future high-energy frontier facilities. He explored how precise measurements of the properties of the newly discovered Higgs boson may shed light on the nature of the “electroweak phase transition”, an event which occurred about a nanosecond after the Big Bang and which determined many of the properties of the universe that we live in today. Perelstein also investigated how ongoing and future experiments at high-energy colliders may observe and study so-called WIMPs, elusive particles hypothesized to make up the dark matter in the universe.

 

Grossman spent most of his time looking for ways to further probe the Standard Model in the flavor, Higgs and neutrino sectors.  Grossman proposed novel theoretical ideas that enable us to probe not only the magnitude but also the structure of the couplings of the newly discovered Higgs boson. For the flavor sector, he constructed a new and general method to generate all sum rules based on flavor symmetries.  With this new development he was able to find new sum rules involving decay rate relations for charmed hadrons, and CP violation asymmetries in decays of the B-meson.  He also introduced new ideas for the fundamental physics underlying neutrino masses, and showed how those can help in understanding the origin of neutrino masses and mixings.

 

Earlier work of Lepage and collaborators helped demonstrate the validity and utility of numerical simulations of strong interaction physics (QCD) for addressing real-world problems.  Numerical simulation is the only known technique that can handle this theory with precision. The work covered by this grant led to the most accurate calculations (0.5 percent) in the history of strong interaction physics. These were applied to problems relevant to experimental work on heavy-quark physics (e.g., B/Bs and D/Ds masses, semi-leptonic and leptonic decays, and mixing), high-precision light-quark physics (e.g., K leptonic decay), the most accurate quark masses in history (relevant for Higgs physics), and the most accurate QCD coupling determinations.
